subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... Jim, I mean this in the nicest possible way: I think you need to run a test. All the interpreted languages I know use symbol tables. The references in the
messageBody:
On Wednesday, September 24, 2003, at 9:07:09 AM, Jim Dixon wrote:

> On Tue, 23 Sep 2003, Ron Jeffries wrote:

>> > Of course. But one of the subthreads in this discussion is that
>> > comments can be made unnecessary by, for example, appropriate choice
>> > of variable/method/class/etc names. This is something that we all do, I
>> > imagine.
>>
>> > But the longer and more meaningful the names, the slower the code ;-)
>>
>> In what language is this true, and why?

> It's probably true in any interpreted language; it takes time to run
> through strings. The longer the strings, the more time it takes.

Jim, I mean this in the nicest possible way: I think you need to run a
test.

All the interpreted languages I know use symbol tables. The references in
the byte code are resolved to indexes or pointers at compile time,
generally not run time. In Java, in which I am not expert, my understanding
is that the code that actually executes has been run through the jitter and
converted to actual machine code. I would expect all the symbol lookups, if
there were any, and if they were slow, to be resolved by then if not
before.

> Also, Java is widely used in applications whose performance is
> dominated by communications. If names are embedded in those
> communications, longer names mean slower communications means
> poorer performance.

Yes, that's true. If names were the bulk of the messages going back and
forth, then longer could be slower. If, as is not uncommonly the case,
what's going back and forth is mostly data -- web pages, movies, sound,
database records -- then the symbols in the queries and responses aren't
likely to be a big fraction of the data transmitted. Clearly this is
application dependent, and encoding dependent.

> This rule should not be true in compute-intensive applications --
> but the more compute-bound the problem, the less likely that Java
> is to be used.

Yes, but this is more a function of its interpretive nature than the length
of the names, I would expect. And somewhere I believe I saw a case where C#
beat C++ on some benchmark. And I have seen Smalltalk beat C++ as well.

> In a month or two I might be able to come back with performance
> figures.

I guess you're very busy. Perhaps a smaller experiment would be possible.
Maybe someone else will do one. But the one that will convince you will be
one that you'll do.

> Elsewhere in this thread I have cited a CACM article that would seem
> to support this rule of thumb.

Yes. I'll check it out and report back if it's interesting ...

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
Analysis kills spontaneity.
The grain once ground into flour germinates no more. -- Henri Amiel
